snippet: In towns and cities across the United States, police officers find themselves playing dual roles as law enforcers and psychiatric social workers.
abstract: Police officers nationwide are finding themselves playing dual roles of law enforcers and psychiatric social workers as county jails and state prisons have become de facto mental institutions; release of video in which Albuquerque police shot and killed James Boyd, mentally ill homeless man, has focused attention on the problem; experts say trend is in part due to reduced state and local mental health services due to financial reasons.

byline.original: By FERNANDA SANTOS and ERICA GOODE
byline.contributor: Fernanda Santos reported from Albuquerque, and Erica Goode from New York. J. David Goodman contributed reporting from New York.

lead_paragraph: In towns and cities across the United States, police officers find themselves playing dual roles as law enforcers and psychiatric social workers.

headline.main: Police Confront Rising Number of Mentally Ill Suspects
headline.print_headline: Police Confront Rising Number of Mentally Ill
